newsitem.title: ITALY: Fiat Auto pessimistic on Italy car market.
newsitem.headline: Fiat Auto pessimistic on Italy car market.

text.p: Fiat Auto sees the Italian car market continuing weak despite good growth globally where the Fiat group has performed well, Fiat Auto managing director Roberto Testore said.
"The Italian market unfortunately remains at a low level," Testore told reporters at the opening of the Bologna Motor Show.
And forecasts for 1997 were not brilliant. "It will be a year similar to 1996. I don't see any grounds for a recovery," he said.
The Italian market this year "will confirm our forecasts of around 1.7 million new car sales, objectively a low level and 30 percent down on the best years in the past," he said.
In 1995, new car registrations in Italy totalled 1.74 million. In 1992, the best year in the domestic industry's history, new registrations were 2.39 million.

Testore said the foreign market was growing at a steady, albeit slow pace. "We are satisfied because compared with an average increase of seven to eight percent, the Fiat group is growing by 23 to 24 percent."
